body: Hi! You can follow #235 issue. My suggestion is to set a breakpoint on the line with this error and check what went wrong.

![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/82496916/152118135-c783ef80-5ac0-4ecf-af43-0e721048c6aa.png)
Hello, after modifying the number of channels, the following problems appear. How to solve this situation
This error means, that network output differs from the target output. Make sure they both have the same shape.

If you have modified network output size, you need to also modify target heatmaps spatial dimensions. So if network outputs `NxCx(H/16)x(W/16)`, then target heatmaps have to be the same shape: `NxCx(H/16)x(W/16)`, where H, W is the network input height and width. Check shape of tensors that went to loss. Internal network architecture can be any, just output has to match the target.

Sorry, after I check, the output H, W, C, N of the replaced mobilenetv3 is the same as that of mobilenetv1, and then print, as shown in the figure:
![333](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/82496916/154787598-17dd8abc-d3de-43a0-a51d-5af3cbbc8ebc.png)
the following problem occurs: torch.Size([32, 19, 23, 23]) torch. Size ([32, 19, 46, 46]). The specific error is shown in the figure below. How can I modify it
![555](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/82496916/154787651-3c182f60-8e71-4f02-8ee2-12adffa082e8.png)
Thank you very much for your guidance！！！The train can run through！！！
Thank you very much for your help. Please explain the theory of changing stride parameter from 8 to 16. I want to understand the truth.

You may check the [previous](https://github.com/Daniil-Osokin/lightweight-human-pose-estimation.pytorch/issues/237#issuecomment-1036547640) answer. Target and predicted tensors have to be the same shape. Stride is the ratio network input bigger output, so bigger stride, smaller network output.

I do not have any. However, you can just use 20% or 10% of COCO (set in dataset object proper length in `__len__` method). This should give smaller, but comparable numbers to the performance with using the full dataset.
Sorry, I'm late. I'm currently in the experiment. Thank you very much for your guidance
Excuse me, why is the modified mobilenetv3 less effective than mobilenetv1? Why?
80% of success is reasonable hypothesis and proper experiments, possibly you need a bit more time, keep trying =)

issue.title: Smile, fingers

repository.name: lightweight-human-pose-estimation.pytorch
repository.description: Fast and accurate human pose estimation in PyTorch. Contains implementation of "Real-time 2D Multi-Person Pose Estimation on CPU: Lightweight OpenPose" paper.

issue.body:
Hello,

Thanks for this model, it's amazing.

## **Question**

I wanted to know, since you trained on coco2017 dataset, this model should be able to detect smiles and fingers poses. 

![hand_result](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47783157/158843362-3589d721-1992-4176-aa66-ba4585ffdf9a.png)
![face_result](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47783157/158843397-574e2ff2-913c-4304-b3c5-ff9109219451.png)

Is it possible? I saw that you guys select which output to show, there 4 outputs of the model and only index -2 is taken (so 3 output of heatmap is used)

## **Hypothesis**
```
    stage2_heatmaps = stages_output[-2]
    heatmaps = np.transpose(stage2_heatmaps.squeeze().cpu().data.numpy(), (1, 2, 0))
    heatmaps = cv2.resize(heatmaps, (0, 0), fx=upsample_ratio, fy=upsample_ratio, interpolation=cv2.INTER_CUBIC)

    stage2_pafs = stages_output[-1]
    pafs = np.transpose(stage2_pafs.squeeze().cpu().data.numpy(), (1, 2, 0))
    pafs = cv2.resize(pafs, (0, 0), fx=upsample_ratio, fy=upsample_ratio, interpolation=cv2.INTER_CUBIC)

    return heatmaps, pafs, scale, pad
```

Is accessing the other 3 results the key to get detection of hand and smile pose ?

Thanks
